paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: (unless the terms of the scheme otherwise provide) such part of the past service liabilities to the beneficiaries of the scheme (if any) which exceeds the vested liabilities thereto as at the date on which the relevant winding-up order is made.

subsection.content: The surplus (if any) remaining after satisfaction of all liabilities mentioned in subsection (2) shall be paid to the person who was the relevant employer of the scheme immediately before the registration of the scheme was cancelled, unless the terms of the scheme otherwise provide. (Amended 9 of 2020 s. 39)

subsection.leadIn: Where the assets of the scheme are not sufficient to meet its liabilities, the court may, notwithstanding any term of the scheme, direct that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: those liabilities which are of a class or description specified by the court shall be discharged before any other liability of the scheme is wholly or partly discharged; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: as between them the discharge of those which are of specified classes or descriptions shall be preferred in an order also specified by the court.

section.name: s57
section.heading: The court’s power after winding up

subsection.content: Where the court makes an order as regards a scheme under section 48(2), the liquidator appointed as regards the scheme may make an application to the court on behalf of any beneficiary of the scheme.

In an application made under subsection (1) as regards a scheme, the liquidator may name the relevant employer or administrator of the scheme or any person who is concerned with the operation and management of the scheme to be the respondent in the application.

subsection.leadIn: On an application made under subsection (1) on behalf of a beneficiary of a scheme, the court may— (Amended 9 of 2020 s. 40)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: determine a sum which in its opinion equals the shortfall (if any) between the beneficiary’s vested benefits under the scheme as at the date of the commencement of the winding up of the scheme and the amount received by him under section 56(2); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if it is satisfied that the shortfall referred to in paragraph (a) is caused by any act or omission of any respondent in the application, give judgment against the respondent for an amount equal to the sum determined under paragraph (a).

section.name: s58
section.heading: Court may give directions
section.content: The court may upon application by a liquidator give such directions as it thinks fit in relation to any matter arising under the winding up.

section.name: s59
section.heading: Exercise of the powers of the court
section.leadIn: Unless otherwise ordered by the court in a particular case, the powers of the court under this Part shall be exercisable by—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Registrar of the High Court;

paragraph.name: aa
paragraph.content: any Senior Deputy Registrar of the High Court; (Added 10 of 2005 s. 183)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any Deputy Registrar of the High Court; or (Amended 10 of 2005 s. 183)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any Assistant Registrar of the High Court appointed by the Registrar of the High Court for the purposes of this section.

section.name: s60
section.heading: Offences relating to winding up
section.leadIn: Any person who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: without reasonable excuse fails to comply with a direction given under section 52(2); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: provides any information or makes any representation which is false in a material particular and which—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: he knows to be false in such particular; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: he has no reasonable ground to believe to be true in such particular,

section.continued: commits an offence and shall be liable on summary conviction to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

subsection.content: Every appeal made under sections 8, 13, 19 and 46 shall be determined by the Appeal Board to be known as the Occupational Retirement Schemes Appeal Board.
The Chief Executive shall appoint a person to be the Chairman of the Appeal Board and such number of persons as he thinks fit to be the Deputy Chairmen of the Appeal Board. (Amended 31 of 1999 s. 3)
Subject to subsection (7), the Chairman or any Deputy Chairman shall be appointed for a term of not more than 2 years but may be reappointed.

subsection.name: 3A
subsection.leadIn: A person appointed under subsection (2) to be the Chairman of the Appeal Board must be—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: a former Justice of Appeal of the Court of Appeal; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a former judge or a former deputy judge of the court. (Added 9 of 2020 s. 41)

subsection.content: A person appointed under subsection (2) to be the Deputy Chairman, or one of the Deputy Chairmen, of the Appeal Board must be a solicitor or barrister admitted under the Legal Practitioners Ordinance (Cap. 159). (Amended 9 of 2020 s. 41)
The Chief Executive shall appoint a panel of persons not being public officers whom he considers suitable for appointment under section 62 as members of the Appeal Board. (Amended 31 of 1999 s. 3)
An appointment under subsection (2) or (5) shall be notified in the Gazette.
The Chairman and any Deputy Chairman or person appointed under subsection (5) may at any time resign by notice in writing to the Chief Executive. (Amended 31 of 1999 s. 3)

The Chairman and any Deputy Chairman or person appointed under subsection (5) shall be remunerated out of money provided by the Legislative Council for that purpose at a rate that the Financial Secretary may determine.

section.name: s62
section.heading: Constitution and powers of Appeal Board

subsection.content: The Appeal Board shall consist of the Chairman or a Deputy Chairman who shall preside at the hearing and such number of persons, not being fewer than 2, from the panel referred to in section 61(5) as the Chairman may appoint to be members of the Appeal Board to hear any appeal.

In relation to the hearing of appeals every question before the Appeal Board shall be determined by the opinion of the majority of the members hearing the appeal except a question of law which shall be determined by the Chairman or (where appropriate) the Deputy Chairman; in the case of an equality of votes the Chairman or Deputy Chairman shall have a casting vote.

subsection.leadIn: In hearing an appeal the Appeal Board may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: receive and consider any material, whether by way of oral evidence, written statements, documents or otherwise, and whether or not it would be admissible in a court of law;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: by notice in writing signed by the Chairman, summon any person—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: to produce to it any document that is relevant to the appeal and is in his custody or under his control; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: to appear before it and to give evidence relevant to the appeal;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: administer oaths and affirmations;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: require evidence to be given on oath or affirmation;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: make an award of such sum, if any, in respect of the costs involved in the appeal as is just and equitable in all the circumstances of the case.

subsection.leadIn: After hearing an appeal made in respect of an occupational retirement scheme—

paragraph.name: aa
paragraph.content: under section 8(1), the Appeal Board may determine the appeal by upholding, varying or quashing the Registrar’s decision, and making any necessary consequential order; (Added 9 of 2020 s. 42)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: under section 8(2), the Appeal Board may determine the appeal by confirming the Registrar’s decision or directing the Registrar to issue an exemption certificate in respect of the scheme; (Amended 9 of 2020 s. 42)

paragraph.name: b
ba
paragraph.content: under section 19(1), the Appeal Board may determine the appeal by upholding, varying or quashing the Registrar’s decision, and making any necessary consequential order; (Added 9 of 2020 s. 42)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: under section 19(2), the Appeal Board may determine the appeal by confirming the Registrar’s decision or directing the Registrar to register the scheme; (Amended 9 of 2020 s. 42)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: under section 46, the Appeal Board may determine the appeal by confirming the Registrar’s decision or directing the Registrar to restore the registration of the scheme.

section.name: s63
section.heading: Appeal Board’s decision is final
section.content: Subject to section 65, the determination of an appeal by the Appeal Board or any order as to costs made by the Appeal Board shall be final.

subsection.content: The procedure and practice of the Appeal Board shall, subject to this Ordinance, be determined by the Chairman.

If the Chairman is precluded by illness, absence from Hong Kong or any other cause from exercising his functions, the Chief Executive may appoint a Deputy Chairman to act as Chairman and as such to exercise all the functions of the Chairman during the period of his appointment. (Amended 31 of 1999 s. 3)

If a person appointed by the Chairman under section 62(1) to hear an appeal is precluded by illness, absence from Hong Kong or any other cause from exercising his functions, the Chairman may appoint any other person from the panel referred to in section 61(5) to act in his place.

In the hearing of an appeal, the appellant and the Registrar shall be entitled to be heard either in person or through a solicitor or barrister and if the appellant is a body corporate, through any of its directors or employees or if a partnership, through any of the partners or, with the leave of the Appeal Board, through any other person.

In relation to any appeal to the Appeal Board, the members of the Appeal Board, the appellant, and any witness, representative or other person appearing before the Appeal Board shall have the same privileges and immunities as they would have if the proceedings were civil proceedings before a court.

Any sum awarded to the Registrar under section 62(3)(e) shall be a debt due to the Registrar and recoverable in the District Court and any sum payable by the Registrar under such an award shall be charged on the MPFA Administration Account established and maintained under section 6M of the Mandatory Provident Fund Schemes Ordinance (Cap. 485). (Amended 4 of 1998 s. 4)

section.name: s65
section.heading: Case may be stated for Court of Appeal

subsection.content: The Appeal Board may refer any question of law arising in an appeal to the Court of Appeal for determination by way of case stated.
On the hearing of the case, the Court of Appeal may amend the case or order it to be sent back to the Appeal Board for amendment.
Where a case is stated under subsection (1), the Appeal Board shall not determine the relevant appeal before the Court of Appeal determines the relevant point of law.

section.name: s66
section.heading: Offences relating to appeal
section.leadIn: Any person who without reasonable excuse refuses or fails—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to attend and give evidence when required to do so by the Appeal Board;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to answer truthfully and completely questions put to him by the Appeal Board;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: to produce any document which he is required by the Appeal Board to produce,

section.continued: commits an offence and shall be liable on summary conviction to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

section.name: s66A
section.heading: Interpretation
section.leadIn: In this Part—
section.def: investigation requirement (調查要求) means a requirement made under section 66D;
scheme (計劃) means a registered scheme or an exempted scheme.

subsection.leadIn: An authorized person may, at any reasonable time during ordinary business hours, enter premises at which the person reasonably believes that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the affairs of a scheme are being conducted; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any information or document relating to a scheme is being kept,

subsection.continued: for the purpose of ascertaining whether or not the provisions of this Ordinance are being complied with or have been complied with.

subsection.content: This section does not authorize an authorized person to enter premises that are being used as a private dwelling.
An authorized person must give the occupier of the premises reasonable notice of the intention to enter the premises.

subsection.leadIn: However, an authorized person may enter premises under this section without giving notice and without the consent of the occupier—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if entry is required urgently and the Registrar has expressly authorized entry; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if giving notice or obtaining the consent would defeat the purpose for which it is intended to exercise the power of entry.

subsection.leadIn: An authorized person who enters premises under this section may do any of the following acts—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: inspect the premises and examine any record found on the premises that the authorized person reasonably believes relates to a scheme;

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.content: require the occupier of the premises or any person who is apparently an employee or agent of that occupier to provide the authorized person with such assistance and facilities as are reasonably necessary to enable the authorized person to perform his or her functions;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: require any person on the premises to produce for inspection records under the control of the person relating to a scheme and, if any such records are not legible or are not in the English or Chinese language, to produce a written statement in English or Chinese setting out the contents of those records;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: make copies of all or any part of any such records or statements.

subsection.leadIn: A person may exercise a power conferred by this section only if the person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is in possession of a warrant of authority issued by the Registrar; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on being requested to do so, produces that warrant to the occupier of the premises sought to be entered, inspected or examined or to any other person in relation to whom it is sought to exercise that power.

subsection.leadIn: The Registrar may investigate any matter if, in relation to a scheme, the Registrar—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: has reasonable cause to believe that a person may have contravened the provisions of this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: has reasonable cause to believe that circumstances may exist that could prejudice the interests of the members of the scheme; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: thinks it is necessary to investigate the matter in order to decide whether to exercise any power under section 11, 12, 42 or 45.

subsection.leadIn: The Registrar may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: carry out the investigation itself; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in writing direct a person employed by the Registrar to carry out the investigation.

subsection.content: In carrying out the investigation, the Registrar or the person referred to in subsection (2)(b) may exercise the powers under section 66D.
If the Registrar directs a person under subsection (2)(b), the Registrar must provide the person with a copy of the direction.
Even though the Registrar has directed a person to carry out an investigation, the Registrar may still exercise the powers under section 66D for the purpose of the investigation.

If section 36(2)(a) applies in relation to a scheme, the Registrar must first appoint a person to conduct an inquiry under section 36 before exercising the power under subsection (2) in relation to the scheme.

subsection.leadIn: An investigator may by written notice require a person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: to produce, within the time and at the place specified in the notice, any record or document specified in the notice—

subparagraph.content: that is or may be relevant to any matter under investigation; and
that is in the person’s possession or under the person’s control;

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.content: to respond to any written question relating to any matter under investigation that the investigator may raise with the person; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: to give the investigator any assistance in connection with the investigation that the person is reasonably able to give.

subsection.content: If a person produces a record or document in compliance with a requirement under subsection (1)(a), the investigator may require the person to give an explanation or further particulars in respect of the record or document.

If a person gives any answer, response, explanation or particulars in compliance with a requirement under subsection (1) or (2), the investigator may by written notice require the person to verify, within the time specified in the notice, the answer, response, explanation or particulars by a statutory declaration.

If, for the reason that the information concerned is not within the person’s knowledge or possession, a person does not give any answer, response, explanation or particulars in compliance with a requirement under subsection (1) or (2), the investigator may by written notice require the person to verify, within the time specified in the notice, that reason and fact by a statutory declaration.

If the investigator is directed under section 66C(2)(b) to carry out the investigation, the investigator must provide a copy of the direction given under the section to a person when making an investigation requirement of the person.

section.name: s66E
section.heading: Offences of failing to comply with investigation requirement

subsection.content: A person commits an offence if the person, without reasonable excuse, fails to comply with an investigation requirement made of the person.
A person commits an offence if the person, with intent to defraud, fails to comply with an investigation requirement made of the person.

A person commits an offence if, being an officer or employee of a company, the person, with intent to defraud, causes or allows the company to fail to comply with an investigation requirement made of the company.
A person is not excused from complying with an investigation requirement made of the person only on the ground that to do so might tend to incriminate the person.

subsection.leadIn: A person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on summary conviction—to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 6 months; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment—to a fine of $200,000 and to imprisonment for 1 year.

subsection.leadIn: A person who commits an offence under subsection (2) or (3) is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on summary conviction—to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 6 months; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment—to a fine of $1,000,000 and to imprisonment for 7 years.

subsection.content: If a member of a professional body is alleged to have committed an offence under subsection (1), (2) or (3), the Registrar may refer the matter to the professional body.

section.name: s66F
section.heading: Offences of giving false or misleading information

subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in purported compliance with an investigation requirement made of the person, the person produces any record or document, or gives any answer, response, explanation or particulars, that is or are false or misleading in a material respect; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the person knows that, or is reckless as to whether, the record, document, answer, response, explanation or particulars is or are false or misleading in a material respect.

subsection.content: A person commits an offence if, in purported compliance with an investigation requirement made of the person, the person, with intent to defraud, produces any record or document, or gives any answer, response, explanation or particulars, that is or are false or misleading in a material respect.

A person commits an offence if, being an officer or employee of a company, the person, with intent to defraud, causes or allows the company, in purported compliance with an investigation requirement made of the company, to produce any record or document, or give any answer, response, explanation or particulars, that is or are false or misleading in a material respect.

subsection.leadIn: A person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on summary conviction—to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 6 months; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment—to a fine of $1,000,000 and to imprisonment for 2 years.

subsection.leadIn: A person who commits an offence under subsection (2) or (3) is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on summary conviction—to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 6 months; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment—to a fine of $1,000,000 and to imprisonment for 7 years.

subsection.content: If a member of a professional body is alleged to have committed an offence under subsection (1), (2) or (3), the Registrar may refer the matter to the professional body.

section.name: s66G
section.heading: Court’s inquiry into failure to comply with investigation requirement

subsection.content: An investigator may, by originating summons, apply to the court for an inquiry into a person’s failure to comply with an investigation requirement.

subsection.leadIn: On application, the court may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: order the person to comply with the requirement within the period specified by the court; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: punish the person, and any other person knowingly involved in the failure, in the same way as if the person and (if applicable) that other person had been guilty of contempt of court.

subsection.content: An originating summons under subsection (1) is to be in Form No. 10 in Appendix A to the Rules of the High Court (Cap. 4 sub. leg. A).

section.name: s66H
section.heading: Criminal proceedings and applications under sections 66E, 66F and 66G

subsection.leadIn: No criminal proceedings may be brought against a person under section 66E or 66F in respect of any conduct if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an application has previously been made against the person under section 66G in respect of the same conduct; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: either—

subparagraph.content: the application remains pending; or
the court has exercised, or declined to exercise, its power under section 66G(2)(b) in relation to the application.

subsection.leadIn: No application may be made against a person under section 66G in respect of any conduct if—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.leadIn: either—

subparagraph.content: those proceedings remain pending; or
because of those proceedings no criminal proceedings may again be lawfully brought against the person under section 66E or 66F in respect of the same conduct.

section.name: s66I
section.heading: Use of incriminating evidence in proceedings

subsection.leadIn: If an investigator requires a person to give an answer or response to any question, or to give an explanation or further particulars, under section 66D, the investigator must ensure that the person has first been informed or reminded of the limitations imposed by subsection (2) on the admissibility in evidence of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the requirement; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the question and the answer or response, or the explanation or particulars.

subsection.leadIn: If—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an investigator requires a person to give an answer or response to any question, or to give an explanation or further particulars, under section 66D; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the answer, response, explanation or particulars might tend to incriminate the person, and the person so claims before giving the answer, response, explanation or particulars,

subsection.continued: the requirement, as well as the question and the answer or response, or the explanation or particulars, are not admissible in evidence against the person in criminal proceedings in a court of law other than those specified in subsection (3).

subsection.leadIn: For subsection (2), the criminal proceedings are those in which the person is charged, in respect of the answer, response, explanation or particulars, with an offence under—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: section 66E or 66F; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: Part V of the Crimes Ordinance (Cap. 200).

section.name: s67
section.heading: Special provisions for schemes covering groups of companies

subsection.content: Subject to this section, an occupational retirement scheme must only cover 1 relevant employer. (Replaced 53 of 1995 s. 21)

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.content: Relevant employers from within a grouping of companies may operate, contribute to or participate in, group occupational retirement scheme that covers 2 or more companies from within the grouping of companies. (Added 53 of 1995 s. 21)

subsection.name: 1B
subsection.content: The relevant employers from within the grouping of companies must jointly or severally by power of attorney nominate one of themselves, or the holding company of a group of companies within the grouping of companies, as the representative employer for the purposes of the scheme. (Added 53 of 1995 s. 21)

subsection.name: 1C
subsection.leadIn: For the purpose of this section—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.def: grouping of companies (公司集團) means companies that are associated companies or are within a group of companies and includes associated companies of a member of a group of companies;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.def: group of companies (同一集團的公司) means a holding company and its subsidiaries;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: companies are regarded as being associated companies if—

subparagraph.name: i
ii
subparagraph.content: one of the companies is a subsidiary of an associated company; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: they are partners under a written partnership agreement. (Added 53 of 1995 s. 21)

subsection.name: 1D
subsection.leadIn: If a relevant employer in a scheme that covers 2 or more employers ceases to comply with a relationship requirement under this section, the relevant employer shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: notify the representative employer and the Registrar within 1 month of ceasing to comply; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: withdraw from the scheme within 3 months or such further time as the Registrar allows in the circumstances, unless within that time the relevant employer resumes compliance. (Added 53 of 1995 s. 21)

subsection.name: 1E
subsection.leadIn: The relevant employer is required to withdraw from a scheme by arranging for either—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the transfer of the rights of the members who are employed by the withdrawing relevant employer and corresponding assets of the scheme to another registered or exempted scheme or, where the affected members are employed outside Hong Kong, to a scheme outside Hong Kong; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the orderly winding up of that part of the scheme that applies to the withdrawing relevant employer. (Added 53 of 1995 s. 21)

subsection.name: 1F
subsection.content: A relevant employer who, without reasonable excuse, fails to notify the representative employer or the Registrar under subsection (1D)(a) commits an offence and is liable on summary conviction to a fine at level 3. (Added 53 of 1995 s. 21)

subsection.name: 1G
subsection.content: A relevant employer commits an offence and is liable on summary conviction to a fine at level 3 if he, without reasonable excuse, fails to withdraw from a scheme as required under subsection (1D)(b) or to make the arrangement as required under subsection (1E)(a) or (b). (Added 53 of 1995 s. 21)

subsection.leadIn: Where an occupational retirement scheme covers 2 or more relevant employers and all of them (except the nominated representative employer) nominate the same representative employer under subsection (1), the following provisions shall apply—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an application made as regards the scheme under section 7, 15, 23(3) or 48(1) by the representative employer shall be deemed to be an application made by each of the employers covered by the scheme;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: payment of a fee payable as regards the scheme under section 9(1) or 28(1) by the representative employer shall discharge the duty of all other employers covered by the scheme to pay such fee;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: an appeal made as regards the scheme under section 8, 13, 19 or 46 by the representative employer shall be deemed to be an appeal made by each of the employers covered by the scheme;

paragraph.name: d
e
paragraph.content: a notice given as regards the scheme by the Registrar under section 7(5B), (5C) or (5D)(a), 11(2)(b), 12(2)(b), 14(2), 14(3)(b), 18(4A), (4B) or (4C)(a), 32(4)(a), 36(4), 39(1), 43(1)(b), 45(2)(b), 47(2) or 47(3)(b) to the representative employer shall, unless otherwise stated in the notice, be deemed to have been given to every employer covered by the scheme; (Amended 53 of 1995 s. 21)

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: the duty of a consultative committee formed by the members of the scheme to give notice or advice to the relevant employer of the scheme under section 34 shall be discharged by giving the notice or advice to the representative employer;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: the duty under section 10(1)(d), (f) and (g) shall be discharged as regards the scheme by the representative employer; (Amended 53 of 1995 s. 21)

paragraph.name: ga
paragraph.leadIn: the representative employer of an exempted scheme shall, for each period of 12 months beginning on the date of the exemption certificate or on an anniversary of the date, give the Registrar—

subparagraph.content: an annual return for the period relating to the scheme in the form and containing the information that may be specified by the Registrar;

subparagraph.leadIn: a written statement as to whether at all times during the period—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: the scheme by its terms limits membership of the scheme to eligible persons; and

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: all members of the scheme are eligible persons;
for a scheme exempted under section 7(4)(a)—documentary evidence to satisfy the Registrar of the validity of the relevant registration or approval during the period; and

for a scheme exempted under section 7(4)(b) or (c)—a written statement of the total number of members of the scheme and the number of the members who were Hong Kong permanent identity card holders on the date of the statement,

paragraph.continued: within 1 month after the expiry of the period or a longer period the Registrar may allow;

paragraph.name: gab
paragraph.leadIn: the representative employer of a registered scheme must, within 1 month after the end of a financial year of the scheme, or a longer period the Registrar may allow, give the Registrar a written statement as to whether at all times during the financial year—

subparagraph.content: the scheme by its terms limits membership of the scheme to eligible persons; and
all members of the scheme are eligible persons; (Added 9 of 2020 s. 44)

paragraph.name: gb
paragraph.content: the representative employer shall notify the Registrar of a change of representative employer within 1 month of the change; (Added 53 of 1995 s. 21)

paragraph.name: gc
paragraph.leadIn: the representative employer shall notify the Registrar of a change to his name or address—

subparagraph.name: i
ii
subparagraph.content: for an exempted scheme for which he is the representative employer as soon as is reasonably practicable after the change; (Added 53 of 1995 s. 21)

paragraph.name: gd
paragraph.content: the representative employer shall notify the Registrar of the matters prescribed in rules and required under section 21A(2) within 1 month after the change to the name of the scheme; (Added 53 of 1995 s. 21)

paragraph.name: ge
paragraph.content: the representative employer of a registered group scheme shall notify the Registrar of any change of the administrator of the scheme as required under section 22(1)(b); (Added 53 of 1995 s. 21)

paragraph.name: gf
paragraph.content: the Registrar may give notice under section 26(1) to the representative employer of a registered group scheme and the representative employer is required to comply with notice given under that section in addition to a requirement placed on a relevant employer under that section and the representative employer may apply for an extension of time under section 26(2); (Added 53 of 1995 s. 21)

paragraph.name: h
i
paragraph.content: an exemption certificate or registration certificate issued under section 7(1) or 18(5) as regards the scheme shall be issued to the representative employer.

subsection.content: A representative employer who without reasonable excuse fails to notify the Registrar under section 10(1)(d) as required under subsection (2)(g) commits an offence and is liable on summary conviction to a fine at level 1. (Added 53 of 1995 s. 21)

A representative employer who without reasonable excuse fails to notify the Registrar under section 10(1)(f) as required under subsection (2)(g) commits an offence and is liable on summary conviction to a fine at level 3. (Added 53 of 1995 s. 21)

A representative employer who without reasonable excuse fails to discharge his duty under subsection (2)(g) in relation to a notice under section 10(1)(g) commits an offence and is liable on summary conviction to a fine at level 6. (Added 53 of 1995 s. 21)

A representative employer who without reasonable excuse fails to notify the Registrar on the change of representative employer as required under this section commits an offence and is liable on summary conviction to a fine at level 3. (Added 53 of 1995 s. 21)

subsection.name: 6A
subsection.content: A representative employer who without reasonable excuse fails to give the Registrar an annual return, a written statement or documentary evidence as required under subsection (2)(ga) commits an offence and is liable on summary conviction to a fine at level 3. (Added 9 of 2020 s. 44)

A representative employer who without reasonable excuse fails to give a notice under subsection (2)(gc) commits an offence and is liable on summary conviction to a fine at level 3. (Added 53 of 1995 s. 21)

A representative employer who without reasonable excuse fails to give notice under subsection (2)(gd) commits an offence and is liable on summary conviction to a fine at level 1. (Added 53 of 1995 s. 21)

A representative employer who without reasonable excuse fails to give notice under subsection (2)(ge) commits an offence and is liable on summary conviction to a fine at level 3. (Added 53 of 1995 s. 21)

A representative employer who without reasonable excuse fails to give a notice under subsection (2)(h) as required under section 29 commits an offence and is liable on summary conviction to a fine at level 3. (Added 53 of 1995 s. 21)

Any thing required to be done under this Ordinance or any statement, report or other document required to be made or prepared under this Ordinance by an auditor in respect of a Hong Kong domiciled scheme or proposed Hong Kong domiciled scheme shall be done, made or prepared by a Hong Kong accountant.

subsection.leadIn: Any thing required to be done under this Ordinance or any statement, report or other document required to be made or prepared under this Ordinance by an auditor in respect of an offshore scheme or proposed offshore scheme shall be done, made or prepared by—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a Hong Kong accountant; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: a person—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: who may lawfully practise as a professional accountant in the country or jurisdiction which is the domicile of the scheme; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: without prejudice to subparagraph (i), who holds such qualification as the Registrar may accept as being of a standard comparable to that of a Hong Kong accountant.

subsection.leadIn: Any thing required to be done under this Ordinance or any statement, report or other document required to be made or prepared under this Ordinance by an auditor in respect of an occupational retirement scheme shall be done, made or prepared by an auditor who is not—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a partner, director or employee of the administrator of the scheme;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the relevant employer of the scheme;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: an associate or employee of the employer; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a person having a contract of service with an employee referred to in paragraph (a) or (c).

subsection.leadIn: Where a statement, report or other document which purports to be made or prepared by an auditor in respect of an occupational retirement scheme is received by the Registrar, the Registrar may require—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person by whom the statement, report or other document purports to have been made or prepared;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the administrator of the scheme; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the relevant employer of the scheme,

subsection.continued: to supply to the Registrar a statement in writing, in a form specified by the Registrar, that the person is not a person referred to in subsection (3)(a), (b), (c) or (d).

section.name: s69
section.heading: Actuaries and solicitors to be independent of relevant employers

subsection.leadIn: Any thing required to be done under this Ordinance or any statement, certificate, report or other document required to be made or prepared under this Ordinance by an actuary or a solicitor in respect of an occupational retirement scheme shall be done, made or prepared by an actuary or solicitor who is not—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the relevant employer of the scheme;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an associate or employee of the employer; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a person having a contract of service with an employee referred to in paragraph (b).

subsection.leadIn: Where a statement, certificate, report or other document which purports to be made or prepared by an actuary or a solicitor in respect of an occupational retirement scheme is received by the Registrar, the Registrar may require—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person by whom the statement, certificate, report or other document purports to have been made or prepared;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the administrator of the scheme; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the relevant employer of the scheme,

subsection.continued: to supply to the Registrar a statement in writing, in a form specified by the Registrar, that the person is not a person referred to in subsection (1)(a), (b) or (c).

subsection.leadIn: Where a certificate, statement or report either accompanies an application for registration or is sent or supplied to the Registrar pursuant to a requirement under this Ordinance, the Registrar may by notice in writing require—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of an application, the applicant; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in any other case, the designated person of the relevant scheme,

subsection.continued: to supply to the Registrar, within such period as is specified in the notice (being a period of not less than 1 month beginning on the date of the notice), particulars of the professional or other qualifications and experience of the person by whom the certificate, statement or report was given, issued or made.

subsection.leadIn: Where the Registrar makes a requirement under subsection (1) and—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the requirement is not complied with; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: having had regard to the purposes of this Ordinance and the result of relevant inquiries (if any) made by him under subsection (3), the Registrar reasonably considers the person by whom such certificate, statement or report was given, issued or made not to be suitably qualified to give, issue or make it,

subsection.continued: he shall refuse to accept the relevant certificate, statement or report.

subsection.content: Where the Registrar issues a notice under subsection (1), he may make such inquiries as he considers appropriate regarding the qualifications or experience of the person by whom the relevant certificate, statement or report was given, issued or made.

section.name: s70A
section.heading: Certain amounts relating to severance payments and long service payments to be paid from vested benefits

subsection.leadIn: In this section—

def.name: Airconditioner
def.leadIn: benefits reduction provision (扣減利益條文) means the following provision of the Employment Ordinance (Cap. 57)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in relation to the reduction of a part of vested benefits by an amount of a severance payment—section 31IA; or

paragraph.name: b

def.name: Airconditioner
def.leadIn: Cap. 57 payment reduction provision (扣減《第57章》款項條文) means the following provision of the Employment Ordinance (Cap. 57)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in relation to the reduction of an amount of a severance payment by a part of vested benefits—section 31I; or

paragraph.name: b

subsection.def: post-transition portion (轉制後部分) has the meaning given by section 1(1) of Schedule 11 to the Employment Ordinance (Cap. 57);
pre-transition portion (轉制前部分) has the meaning given by section 1(1) of Schedule 11 to the Employment Ordinance (Cap. 57);
specified employee (指明僱員) has the meaning given by section 2(1) of the Employment Ordinance (Cap. 57). (Added 4 of 2022 s. 32)

subsection.leadIn: If—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an employer has paid to or in respect of an employee a severance payment or long service payment in accordance with the Employment Ordinance (Cap. 57), or a part of such a payment; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: vested benefits are held in an occupational retirement scheme in respect of the employee; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a part of those benefits is available to be reduced by an amount of the severance payment or long service payment, or the part of such a payment, that has been so paid (removable benefits) under the benefits reduction provision, (Replaced 4 of 2022 s. 32)

subsection.continued: the employer may make an application in writing to the administrator of the scheme for payment of an amount under subsection (2).

subsection.content: As soon as practicable after receiving an application under subsection (1), the administrator of the occupational retirement scheme concerned must, on being satisfied as to the employer’s entitlement to a payment under this subsection, pay to the employer from the vested benefits concerned an amount equal to the amount of the removable benefits. (Replaced 4 of 2022 s. 32)

subsection.leadIn: However, if the employer has only paid a part of the severance payment or long service payment (paid Cap. 57 payment), the payment under subsection (2) must be of an amount equal to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: if the employee is not a specified employee—the lesser of the following—

subparagraph.content: the amount of the removable benefits;

so much of the vested benefits mentioned in subsection (1)(b) that are employer-funded (specified) ORS benefits and that would remain if they were to be reduced by an amount of the unpaid part of the severance payment or long service payment (unpaid Cap. 57 payment) under the benefits reduction provision; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: if the employee is a specified employee—the sum of the amounts under subparagraphs (i) and (ii)—

subparagraph.leadIn: the lesser of the following—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: so much of the removable benefits that are such benefits because of a reduction by an amount of the pre-transition portion of the paid Cap. 57 payment;

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: so much of the vested benefits mentioned in subsection (1)(b) that are employer-funded ORS benefits and that would remain if they were to be reduced by an amount of the pre-transition portion of the unpaid Cap. 57 payment under the benefits reduction provision;

subparagraph.leadIn: the lesser of the following—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: so much of the removable benefits that are such benefits because of a reduction by an amount of the post-transition portion of the paid Cap. 57 payment;

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: so much of the vested benefits mentioned in subsection (1)(b) that are employer-funded (specified) ORS benefits and that would remain if they were to be reduced by an amount of the post-transition portion of the unpaid Cap. 57 payment under the benefits reduction provision. (Added 4 of 2022 s. 32)

subsection.name: 2B
subsection.content: For the purposes of subsection (2A)(a)(ii) and (b)(i)(B) and (ii)(B), a reduction under the benefits reduction provision is a reduction under the provision that applies on the basis that the unpaid Cap. 57 payment had also been paid. (Added 4 of 2022 s. 32)

subsection.leadIn: If—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an employer has not paid the whole of a severance payment or long service payment to or in respect of an employee as required by the Employment Ordinance (Cap. 57); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: vested benefits are held in an occupational retirement scheme in respect of the employee; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a part of those benefits is available to reduce an amount of the severance payment or long service payment, or the part of such a payment, that has not been so paid (deductible benefits) under the Cap. 57 payment reduction provision, (Replaced 4 of 2022 s. 32)

subsection.continued: an application may be made in writing by or in respect of the employee to the administrator of the scheme for payment of an amount under subsection (4).

subsection.content: As soon as practicable after receiving an application under subsection (3), the administrator of the occupational retirement scheme concerned must, on being satisfied as to the recipient’s entitlement to a payment under this subsection, pay to or in respect of the employee from the vested benefits concerned an amount equal to the amount of the deductible benefits. (Amended 4 of 2022 s. 32)

subsection.leadIn: If—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: a change has occurred (whether by virtue of a sale or other disposition or by operation of law) in the ownership of a business in which a person is employed, or in a part of such a business, and either—

subparagraph.name: i
ii
subparagraph.content: the person is re-engaged by that new owner under a new contract of employment; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a person is taken into the employment of an associated company of another company by which the person was employed immediately before the person was taken into that employment,

subsection.continued: this section applies to a severance payment or long service payment, or a contribution, paid by the previous owner as if it had been paid by the new owner or the associated company. This subsection has effect whether or not the previous owner may have terminated the employee’s contract in accordance with section 6 or 7 of the Employment Ordinance (Cap. 57).

subsection.content: For the purposes of subsection (6), 2 companies are taken to be associated companies if one is the subsidiary of the other, or both are subsidiaries of a further company.

This section also applies, with any necessary modifications, to an occupational retirement scheme within the meaning of the Employment Ordinance (Cap. 57) that is not an occupational retirement scheme within the meaning of this Ordinance.

If an employee falls within section 31ZEA(3) of the Employment Ordinance (Cap. 57), then this section as in force immediately before the date on which the Employment and Retirement Schemes Legislation (Offsetting Arrangement) (Amendment) Ordinance 2022 (4 of 2022) (Amendment Ordinance) comes into operation* continues to have effect in relation to the employee as if the amendments to this section made by the Amendment Ordinance had not been made. (Added 4 of 2022 s. 32)

The relevant employer of a registered scheme or an exempted scheme (receiving scheme) must not accept a transfer of benefits from another scheme (transferring scheme) except in the circumstances set out in subsection (2).

subsection.leadIn: The circumstances are that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the transferring scheme is a registered scheme or an exempted scheme, and—

subparagraph.content: the benefits are payable to a member of the receiving scheme who was a member of the transferring scheme; and

the benefits are held in an account in the name of the member under the transferring scheme before the transfer, and in an account in the name of the member under the receiving scheme after the transfer; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the transferring scheme is not a registered scheme or an exempted scheme but is a provident, pension, retirement or superannuation scheme (however described) established outside Hong Kong, and—

subparagraph.content: the transfer is made directly from the transferring scheme to the receiving scheme;

the benefits are attributable solely to payments to the transferring scheme due to the previous employment of a member by the employer of that scheme, and held in an account in the sole name of the member under that scheme before the transfer;
the member referred to in subparagraph (ii) is a member of the receiving scheme; and
the benefits are held in an account in the name of the member under the receiving scheme after the transfer.

section.name: s71
section.heading: Chief Executive may amend Schedules
section.text: The Chief Executive may amend any Schedule by order published in the Gazette.

section.name: s72
section.heading: Legislative Council may substitute percentage and number
section.content: The Legislative Council may by resolution substitute the percentage or number of persons in section 7(4)(b), 7(4)(c), 11(1)(b), 12(1)(b), 27(2)(a) or 32(1)(a)(iii).

subsection.leadIn: The Registrar may make rules—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.def: for the purposes of the definition of associate; (Amended E.R. 5 of 2021)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.def: for the purposes of the definition of insurance arrangement; (Amended E.R. 5 of 2021)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.def: prescribing fees for the purposes of the definition of prescribed fee; (Amended E.R. 5 of 2021)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: in relation to registration of occupational retirement schemes under this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: da
paragraph.content: for details to be supplied on notice of changes to registered schemes, exempted schemes and pooling agreements; (Added 53 of 1995 s. 22)

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: for the purposes of section 24(3)(a)(iii);

paragraph.name: ea
paragraph.content: for the purposes of section 24A and, in particular, for the purposes of determining when a contribution becomes due; (Added 4 of 1998 s. 4)

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: for the purposes of the requirement of section 25(2);

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: providing for passing of resolutions referred to in section 20(5)(c) or 35(3)(b);

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: providing for the preparation of actuarial certificates to be supplied under this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: for the purposes of section 31;

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.content: providing for the formation, constitution, proceedings and dissolution of consultative committees;

paragraph.name: k
paragraph.content: providing for other matters incidental or related to consultative committees;

paragraph.name: l
paragraph.content: requiring any designated person to give to him notice of any proposed amendment to the relevant registered scheme, being a proposed amendment which is of a class or description so specified;

paragraph.name: m
paragraph.content: for the purposes of section 37;

paragraph.name: n
paragraph.content: in relation to the calculation of unpaid contribution for the purpose of section 38(1)(cf) of the Bankruptcy Ordinance (Cap. 6) and section 265(1)(cf) of the Companies (Winding Up and Miscellaneous Provisions) Ordinance (Cap. 32); (Amended 28 of 2012 ss. 912 & 920)

paragraph.name: na
paragraph.content: without prejudice to section 18(1)(c), specifying the method or methods to be used to pay benefits payable to members of registered schemes; (Added 59 of 1993 s. 23)

paragraph.name: nb
paragraph.leadIn: where a registered scheme is the subject of or regulated by an insurance arrangement, restricting—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.leadIn: the investments which the administrator of the scheme may make in relation to—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: the relevant employer of the scheme or an associate of such employer;

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: any non-listed company within the meaning of section 27(1);

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the loans which that administrator may make to that employer or associate (excluding any loan which is a deposit made with an authorized institution within the meaning of the Banking Ordinance (Cap. 155)); (Added 59 of 1993 s. 23)

paragraph.name: o
paragraph.content: generally for the better carrying out of the provisions and objects of this Ordinance.

subsection.content: Rules made under subsection (1) may make different provisions as regards occupational retirement schemes of different classes or descriptions.
Rules made under subsection (1)(nb) shall be subject to the approval of the Legislative Council. (Added 59 of 1993 s. 23)

section.name: s73A
section.heading: Prescribed fee on notice
section.content: A person who notifies the Registrar of a change of the particulars of a registered scheme or an exempted scheme shall pay the prescribed fee for giving the notice.

section.name: s74
section.heading: Jurisdiction of Court of First Instance

subsection.leadIn: The court shall, in relation to a scheme (including any trust by which the scheme is governed) which is, or has at any time been, a registered scheme and whose domicile is not Hong Kong, have jurisdiction to hear and determine (in accordance with the law of the scheme’s domicile)—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: the amount of any benefit to which any particular person is entitled, or prospectively entitled, under the scheme.

subsection.content: The jurisdiction conferred by subsection (1) shall be without prejudice to any other jurisdiction exercisable by any court, and accordingly nothing in this section shall be regarded as limiting or otherwise affecting any right or other cause of action, existing apart from this section, on the basis of which damages or any other relief or remedy may be recovered or obtained in legal proceedings.
Subsection (1) shall not be construed as affecting in any way any provision of a scheme referred to in that subsection which relates to arbitration.

None of the references to a person or persons in subsection (1) shall be construed as including a reference to a person, including the head of a consulate-general, consulate, vice-consulate or consular agency, entrusted in the capacity of a consular officer with the exercise of consular functions.
A person to whom this section applies is not civilly liable for an act done or omitted to be done by the person in good faith in performing or purportedly performing a function under this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: This section applies to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Registrar;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a director of the Registrar;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: an employee of the Registrar;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: an authorized person;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: a person appointed under section 36(2);

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: an investigator; and

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: a public officer.

section.name: s76
section.heading: Legal professional privilege
section.content: A barrister or solicitor admitted under the Legal Practitioners Ordinance (Cap. 159) shall not be required under this Ordinance to disclose any information (other than the name and address of a client) or produce any record or other document which he would be entitled to refuse to disclose or produce on grounds of legal professional privilege in the court.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to sections 32, 78, 78A and 78B and subsection (2), any person who acquires any information by virtue of his performance or assistance in the performance of functions under this Ordinance shall preserve secrecy with regard to such information and without prejudice to the foregoing shall not— (Amended 1 of 2015 s. 56; 40 of 2021 s. 104)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: disclose such information to any other person except where such disclosure is necessary to such performance or assistance; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: suffer or permit any other person to have access to such information except where such access is necessary for that other person to perform or assist in the performance of functions under this Ordinance.

subsection.content: Nothing in this section shall be construed as prohibiting disclosure of such information in pursuance of a court order, a rule of law or a requirement made under a rule of law.
Any person who contravenes subsection (1) commits an offence and shall be liable on summary conviction to a fine at level 4.(Amended E.R. 5 of 2021)

subsection.leadIn: Notwithstanding section 77, the Registrar may disclose information—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the form of a summary compiled from information provided by persons under this Ordinance if the summary is so compiled as to prevent particulars relating to the business or identity of any such person being ascertained from it;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: with a view to the institution of, or otherwise for the purposes of, any criminal proceedings or any investigation in Hong Kong;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in connection with any civil proceedings to which the Registrar is a party;

paragraph.name: ca
paragraph.content: for seeking advice from, or the giving of advice by, a barrister or solicitor or other professional adviser acting or proposing to act in a professional capacity in connection with a matter arising under this Ordinance; (Added 9 of 2020 s. 47)

paragraph.name: cb
paragraph.content: in a form the Registrar considers appropriate but only if the information has been made available to the public by virtue of being disclosed in any circumstances in which, or for any purpose for which, disclosure is not prohibited under section 77; (Added 9 of 2020 s. 47)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: subject to subsections (1A) and (2), to the Chief Executive, the Financial Secretary, the Secretary for Justice or the Commissioner of Inland Revenue; (Amended L.N. 96 of 1993; 31 of 1999 s. 3; L.N. 106 of 2002; 9 of 2020 s. 47)

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.leadIn: relating to an offshore scheme domiciled in a country, territory or place outside Hong Kong to a supervisory authority which in the Registrar’s opinion—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: performs in that country, territory or place functions which are generally analogous to the functions conferred on the Registrar by this Ordinance; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: is subject to adequate secrecy provisions in that country, territory or place,

paragraph.continued: if the Registrar reasonably considers that such disclosure is in the interests of the members of the scheme as a whole; (Amended 31 of 1999 s. 3)

paragraph.name: ea
paragraph.content: to the Authority, within the meaning of section 2 of the Mandatory Provident Fund Schemes Ordinance (Cap. 485), if, in the opinion of the Registrar, the disclosure will enable or assist the Authority to perform a function conferred or imposed on the Authority by that Ordinance or any other law; (Added 4 of 1998 s. 4)

paragraph.name: eb
paragraph.leadIn: to the Insurance Authority, the Monetary Authority, the Securities and Futures Commission, The Ombudsman or the Accounting and Financial Reporting Council continued under section 6 of the Accounting and Financial Reporting Council Ordinance (Cap. 588) if, in the opinion of the Registrar— (Amended L.N. 66 of 2022)

subparagraph.content: the disclosure is in the interests of the members of the scheme concerned;
the disclosure is in the public interest; or

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.leadIn: to such bodies as then have been specified for the purpose of this paragraph by the Registrar in a notice published in the Gazette if, and only if, the Registrar—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: is satisfied that the information will be used only for the purposes of disciplinary proceedings regarding a member of that body or for the purpose of considering the institution of such proceedings; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: is of the opinion that such disclosure is desirable or expedient; (Amended 9 of 2020 s. 47)

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: with the consent of the person from whom the information was obtained or received and, if the information relates to another person, with the consent also of that other person; or (Added 9 of 2020 s. 47)

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.leadIn: to the public on any details of, or reasons for—

subparagraph.content: the Registrar’s exercise of power under section 11, 12, 14, 42, 43, 45 or 47; or
the Registrar’s application under section 44,

paragraph.continued: and any material facts of the case. (Added 9 of 2020 s. 47)

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.leadIn: The Registrar may only disclose information under subsection (1)(d) if the Registrar is of the opinion that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the disclosure is in the interests of the members of the scheme concerned;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the disclosure is in the public interest; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the disclosure enables the performance of a function conferred by law. (Added 9 of 2020 s. 47)

subsection.content: The Registrar shall not disclose any information to the Commissioner of Inland Revenue under subsection (1)(d) unless the Registrar is satisfied that the information is required by the Commissioner for the purpose of assisting him to determine a question or matter which under the Inland Revenue Ordinance (Cap. 112) is for the Commissioner to determine.

Where information is disclosed to any person under subsection (1)(f) neither that person nor any person obtaining or receiving the information, whether directly or indirectly, from that person shall disclose the information to any other person without the written consent of the Registrar.
Any person who contravenes subsection (3) commits an offence and shall be liable on summary conviction to a fine at level 4.(Amended E.R. 5 of 2021)

section.name: s78A
section.heading: Disclosure by administrator or relevant employer

subsection.leadIn: Despite section 77, an administrator or the relevant employer of an occupational retirement scheme may disclose information if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Registrar has given written consent; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: any of the following applies—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the person to whom the information relates has given written consent;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the information is disclosed in a manner that prevents particulars relating to the identity of the person to whom the information relates from being ascertained from the information.

subsection.leadIn: The Registrar may give consent only if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the information is to be disclosed to a person located in a place outside Hong Kong;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the person exercises or performs in that place functions that correspond to those of the Commissioner of Inland Revenue; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the Registrar is satisfied that the disclosure will enable or assist the person to exercise or perform the person’s official functions.

subsection.content: The Registrar may, in giving consent, impose conditions that it considers appropriate.

section.name: s78B
section.heading: Disclosure for purposes of section 50B or 50C of Inland Revenue Ordinance

subsection.content: Section 77 does not prevent a person from disclosing any information acquired as described under section 77(1) if the disclosure is for the purposes of section 50B or 50C of the Inland Revenue Ordinance (Cap. 112).
Any information disclosed under subsection (1) may be used or disclosed only for the purposes mentioned in that subsection.
A person who uses or discloses any information in contravention of subsection (2) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 4.

section.name: s79
section.heading: General offences of certain fraudulent acts

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.content: This section does not apply in relation to an act that constitutes an offence under section 66E or 66F. (Added 9 of 2020 s. 48)

subsection.leadIn: Any person who in purported compliance with the provisions of this Ordinance or a requirement made under this Ordinance makes any statement or certification of facts which is false in a material particular and which—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: he knows to be false in such particular; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: he has no reasonable ground to believe to be true in such particular,

subsection.continued: commits an offence.

subsection.leadIn: Any person who conceals, destroys, mutilates or falsifies any document or record affecting or relating to the assets or affairs of any occupational retirement scheme with the intention of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: concealing any offence under this Ordinance; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: obstructing any public officer, person appointed under section 36(2) or liquidator appointed under section 49(1) in the performance of his functions under this Ordinance,

subsection.continued: commits an offence.

subsection.leadIn: A person who commits an offence under subsection (1) or (2) is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on summary conviction—to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 6 months; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment—to a fine of $1,000,000 and to imprisonment for 2 years. (Replaced 9 of 2020 s. 48)

subsection.leadIn: Where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a member of a professional body is alleged to have committed an offence under subsection (1) or (2); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it appears to the Registrar that a member of a professional body has committed any act or omission which may constitute professional misconduct relating to an occupational retirement scheme,

subsection.continued: the Registrar may refer that matter to that professional body.

section.name: s79A
section.heading: Offences of obstructing performance of functions etc.

subsection.content: This section does not apply in relation to an act that constitutes an offence under section 66E or 66F.

subsection.leadIn: A person must not—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: without lawful authority, obstruct or hinder, or interfere with, the Registrar, an authorized person or an investigator in the performance of a function under this Ordinance; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: without reasonable excuse, fail to comply with a requirement made by the Registrar, the authorized person or the investigator in the course of performing such a function.

subsection.leadIn: A person who contravenes subsection (2) commits an offence and is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on a first conviction—to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 6 months; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on each subsequent conviction—to a fine of $200,000 and to imprisonment for 1 year.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: summary offence (簡易程序罪行) means an offence triable summarily only.

subsection.leadIn: A prosecution for a summary offence under this Ordinance may only be started before the later of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the end of 3 years after the date on which the offence is committed; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the end of 6 months after the date on which the offence is discovered by, or comes to the notice of, the Registrar.

statutoryNote.heading: Note—
statutoryNote.content: This replaces the time limit under section 26 of the Magistrates Ordinance (Cap. 227).

subsection.content: Subsection (2) does not apply in relation to an offence committed before the date* on which the Occupational Retirement Schemes (Amendment) Ordinance 2020 (9 of 2020) comes into operation.

section.name: s79C
section.heading: Proof of reasonable excuse or lawful authority
section.leadIn: In proceedings for an offence under this Ordinance, the defendant is to be taken to have established that the defendant had a reasonable excuse or lawful authority for the contravention in question if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: sufficient evidence is adduced to raise an issue that the defendant had such a reasonable excuse or lawful authority; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the contrary is not proved by the prosecution beyond reasonable doubt.

section.name: s80
section.heading: Registrar may require English or Chinese version of certain documents

subsection.content: Where a document given to the Registrar or an appointed person within the meaning of section 36 in purported compliance with a requirement of or under this Ordinance is not written in either the English or Chinese language, the Registrar may by notice in writing require the person of whom the requirement was made to send to him within such period as is specified in the notice (being a period of not less than 1 month after the date of the notice) an English or Chinese version of the document as the person may elect.
Any person who fails to comply with a requirement under subsection (1) commits an offence and shall be liable on summary conviction to a fine at level 3.(Amended E.R. 5 of 2021)

section.name: s80A
section.heading: Registrar may appoint or authorize persons
section.content: The Registrar may in writing appoint or authorize a person to perform functions, or specified functions, under or for the purposes of this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: A notice required to be given under this Ordinance to a person shall be properly given if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in case such person is an individual, it is delivered to him or sent by post to him at the address at which he ordinarily resides or carries on business or, if such an address is unknown, at his last known address; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in case such person is a company, it is sent by post to the company’s registered office in Hong Kong; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in case such person is a non-Hong Kong company as defined by section 2(1) of the Companies Ordinance (Cap. 622), it is sent by post to the principal place of business of the company in Hong Kong; or (Amended 30 of 2004 s. 3; 28 of 2012 ss. 912 & 920)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: in case such person is a body corporate other than a company (whether incorporated or otherwise established in Hong Kong or elsewhere), or an unincorporated body of persons, it is sent by post to any address at which the body carries on business.

subsection.content: For the purposes of subsection (1), every body corporate other than a company and every unincorporated body of persons not being a partnership shall be deemed to carry on business at its principal office or place of business.

Where an offence under this Ordinance is committed by a corporation and is proved to have been committed with the consent or connivance of, or to be attributable to any neglect on the part of, any director, manager, secretary, or other similar officer of the corporation (and whether so called or not), or any person who was purporting to act in any such capacity, he as well as the corporation, shall be guilty of the offence and shall be liable to be proceeded against and punished accordingly.

Where an offence under this Ordinance committed by a partner is proved to have been committed with the consent or connivance of, or to be attributable to any neglect on the part of, any other partner of the relevant partnership, that other partner shall be guilty of the offence and shall be liable to be proceeded against and punished accordingly.

section.name: s85
section.heading: Schemes falling short of membership requirements

subsection.leadIn: This section applies in relation to a scheme that has been held out as being an occupational retirement scheme and would be an occupational retirement scheme except for either or both of the following matters—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a term of the scheme allows a person other than an eligible person to be a member of the scheme;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: not all members of the scheme are eligible persons.

subsection.content: Any requirement or duty imposed under this Ordinance on a relevant employer applies to the person described as an employer in the terms of the scheme, or to the person held out as a relevant employer in relation to the scheme.
Any function that may be performed under this Ordinance in relation to an occupational retirement scheme may be performed in relation to the scheme.

section.name: s86
section.heading: Transitional provisions for Occupational Retirement Schemes (Amendment) Ordinance 2020

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: Amendment Ordinance (《修訂條例》) means the Occupational Retirement Schemes (Amendment) Ordinance 2020 (9 of 2020);
*commencement date (生效日期) means the date on which the Amendment Ordinance comes into operation;
pre-amended Ordinance (《未經修訂條例》) means this Ordinance as in force immediately before the commencement date.

subsection.content: If, on the commencement date, an application for exemption or registration of an occupational retirement scheme that the Registrar has received before the commencement date is not finally disposed of as described in section 3(4), the pre-amended Ordinance continues to apply in relation to the application as if the Amendment Ordinance had not been enacted.

subsection.leadIn: If—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an exemption certificate has been issued in respect of an occupational retirement scheme; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the date of the certificate, or an anniversary of the date, falls before the commencement date,

subsection.continued: sections 10 and 67 of the pre-amended Ordinance continue to apply in relation to the period of 12 months beginning on the date of the certificate or on the anniversary as if the Amendment Ordinance had not been enacted, even if part of the period falls on or after the commencement date.

subsection.content: If a financial year of a registered scheme begins before the commencement date, sections 30 and 67 of the pre-amended Ordinance continue to apply in relation to the financial year as if the Amendment Ordinance had not been enacted, even if part of the financial year falls on or after the commencement date.

heading.inline: Basic Documents for a Scheme which is not a Participating Scheme of a Pooling Agreement

section.name: s1
section.leadIn: A statement by a solicitor stating—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: either—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: that the occupational retirement scheme to which the application relates is governed by a trust; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: that such scheme is the subject of or regulated by an insurance arrangement; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: that such scheme is neither governed by a trust nor the subject of or regulated by an insurance arrangement;

paragraph.name: b
ba
paragraph.content: that the scheme by its terms limits membership of the scheme to eligible persons; (Added 9 of 2020 s. 52)

paragraph.name: c
d
paragraph.leadIn: that the terms of the scheme—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: do not enable any person, without the consent of the scheme’s member concerned, to alter to the member’s detriment either his accrued rights under the scheme or his vested benefits, unless such alteration is consequential upon an amendment to the terms of the scheme consented to by not less than 90% of the members of the scheme; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: provide that where an alteration described in sub-subparagraph (i) occurs, any vested benefit which the member concerned is entitled to receive as at the date of such alteration under the terms of the scheme as if the condition precedent (if any) of such entitlement had been satisfied shall, if he so elects, become payable to him; (Amended 59 of 1993 s. 24)

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: that the terms of the scheme have the effect provided for in section 18(1)(c) and (d); and (Amended 59 of 1993 s. 24)

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.leadIn: where the scheme is the subject of or regulated by an insurance arrangement, that the terms of that arrangement provide that the sum, if any, payable by the administrator of the scheme in the event of the termination of that arrangement may be paid by the administrator only to—

subparagraph.name: i
ii
subparagraph.content: a person who will hold that sum on trust as an asset of that scheme in accordance with the provisions of section 25. (Added 59 of 1993 s. 24)

section.name: s1A
section.leadIn: For an occupational retirement scheme in respect of which there is an application for registration—a statement by an auditor stating, as at a date within 3 months before the date of application—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: whether or not, in the auditor’s opinion, all members of the scheme are eligible persons in all material respects; and

(Amended 9 of 2020 s. 52)

paragraph.name: a

subparagraph.name: i
